text: - Hello, and welcome to Community Chats.

I'm Aley Hammer and today we're
joined with Paul Thompson
from TYRO Payments.
Paul, welcome to the show.
Can you start by telling our audience
a little bit about TYRO Payments?
- Yeah, so TYRO Payments is, as it sounds,
a payments company.

We started out as offering
acquiring only in 2003

and eventually grew to
become all full banking

range of banking products for
businesses across Australia.

So deposits, loans, and
obviously acquiring,

along with health claiming and
private claiming and rebates.

- And Paul, Tap, which
is TYRO's app platform,
builds on AWS as a true rocket ship

and I've seen so many of our
specialist solution architects

being completely blown
away with the technology.
I know you're really humble, Paul,

but can you tell us a little
bit about the cloud journey
with Tap?

- Sure, So Tap is TYRO
Application Platform.

It's our app platform for
running containerized workloads
on top of EKS with Istio.

I guess it is, took our
learnings from on premise
and running microservices there,
and then leveraging, you know,
the open source tools that exist today

to make that whole thing
a better experience
and I guess the interesting bits of it is

we sort of jumped on the
GitOps bandwagon quite early,
a couple years ago,

and built that out by
also building a couple

of abstractions on top
of Kubernetes in SDO
to help make the experience better
for our product engineers.
So one of those things is called Schooner,

which is a Kubernetes operator
that abstracts away, sorry,

Kubernetes in SDO
for a couple of reasons.

So it gives a nicer interface
for product engineers

to deal with when running
their workloads on top of Tap.

Be it via, you know,
sensible default configuration
and just nicer things to reckon with,

not having to become experts
in the underlying technology.
But it also helps our platform team

because they're no longer
having to get product engineers
to upgrade things when we want to change
like SDO versions,
if SDO were to deprecate some API's.

Now the Schooner interface
that sits in the middle,
kind of acts as an adapter between the two

and allows the platform
team to move freely,

stay up to date and stay on
top of what we've, sorry,
the latest versions of Kubernetes and SDO,

and again, empowering the
product engineering teams
to kind of leverage those features.

As we've continued along
the GitOps journey,
we've also introduced Argo CD
as a way to synchronize desired state

with our clusters, as per
the GitOps sort of principle
and again, we introduced another operator
for that as well called Slipways,

keeping with the nautical
theme, and it is basically,

again an abstraction over
some of the Argo CD details.

It just gives teams a
nice interface to just say
this is where my manifests live,
and not have to worry about, you know,

all of the specifics of
how to configure Argo,

and it will just deploy them
to the appropriate clusters.

- There have been so
many awesome learnings
from the Tap technology.
So thank you so much for sharing and Paul,

what are some of the
initiatives that keep you
and the engineering teams occupied

'cause I know you guys
are slammed at the moment.

- Sure, so I guess apart
from ongoing maintenance
of the Tap cluster and, you know,
constantly upgrading Kubernetes and SDO,
which are quite fast moving pieces,
we are looking at a couple of things.

One being our POS integration,
which is something
that comes from the early days of TYRO
and it's one of TYRO's big selling points,
is the amount of POS we integrate with.

The technology that was
built on has served as well
for the last 10 plus years.

But now we are looking at how
we can basically reimagine it
to scale for the next 10

and one of the ways we're
doing that is by looking at

AWS IoT as a platform
potentially for doing this.

So I guess that combined
with device management,

which terminals and POS's
wouldn't traditionally

be things you would imagine
is IoT type devices,

but then when you look at
the way we interact with them
and what we have to do with them,
it does quite fit that model nicely.
So we are investigating the IoT platform,
doing a bit of a proof of concept
and spike on that at the moment

and some of the, you know,
monitoring device management

and rules and things that
are built into that service
seem to be quite nice tools for the job
we need to achieve with them.

- Those are some really cool
projects keeping you guys busy

and I guess what I wanna
know is if we had to wrap up

this interview, what would
you like to have built
over the next two, three years?

- Sure, so one of the major
things we're looking at doing
is revamping our whole CICD pipeline.

It was built at the beginning
of our cloud journey,
back in 2018, but as time has gone on,

there's been a lot of
movement in the industry
that we would like to, you know

leverage some of the new
tooling that's come out.

We wanna reimagine the
whole thing as a sort of
event driven process,
leveraging a lot of AWS services,
but also leverage a lot of the tooling

and things have come out now
around supply chain security
and providence.
So things like Project SIG Store

and tools like the
framework, like In-Toto
and tools like Cosign to basically look at
how we improve our security posture.

So signing artifacts
all the way from source

and testing to them before
they run in production

and then along with
that, I guess improving
the developer experience to improve
the sort of the dev feedback loop.
So as you know,

you move to a more and
more cloud based world,

things where you would used
to do a lot of local testing
on your machine have less validity

because you now need to
test against services

and in the, you know inside
of different environments,
Kubernetes.
So there's tools like Tilt and Scaffold,
which aim to solve that problem

by allowing you to quickly
synchronize changes locally
into a running cluster,

test your changes fast
without having to go
through a whole CICD pipeline,
before you get to just validate
the thing that you've written works.

So we were looking to basically
improve the dev experience
and better speed up the dev feedback loop
or tighten the dev feedback loop,

basically to improve
the develop experience
and help them leverage the cluster better.

- Paul, thank you so much
for coming on the show.

I know so many companies out
there will really learn a lot
from TYRO and your journey with AWS
and if anyone does have any questions,

please pop them in the
comment section below,
and we'll get back to you.
Thanks so much for joining us.
- Thank you.
